title: Assessing the Cultural Effects of Climate Change on Northwest Tribes

Items.name: Interviews conducted by Dr. Sammantha Chishom Hatfield

summary: Tribal communities have spiritually rich and complex connections with the natural environment, and their traditions, identities, and economies rely heavily on local natural resources. Because of this intimate connection with nature, tribes are especially vulnerable to climate changes that disrupt their surroundings. Surprisingly, however, few studies have delved deeply into Native thinking around climate change and its cultural impacts. This project sought to understand the ways in which Native American culture and cultural practices in the northwestern U.S. have been affected by climate change. Researchers conducted in-depth interviews with tribal elders and cultural experts belonging to three Northwest tribes – the Confederated Tribes [...]

contacts.name: Philip W Mote
contacts.description: Record created from UCRB Mendeley data.

history:
Restrictions exist based on IRB protocols.  Oral interviews will likely not be archived.  Transcriptions/analysis will be.
(8/11/2014)
Much discussion regarding redaction, transfer.  Instructed by OSU IRB to give Mote direct access to a ScienceBase record to which to upload.
On instruction from Emily Fort, created a basic metadata record to describe the set of transcripts.  Following that, they will be released.
Data has been released and is now available.
(6/25/2015)
